Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Walking Crutch/Cane for Enhanced Assistance, Balance, and Control of Walking Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Six million Americans use crutches, canes, or walkers for mobility assistance due to chronic conditions and more than 10 million Americans use crutches due to temporary injuries. Users who commonly require walking assistance using crutches or a walking cane include individuals with cerebral palsy, stroke and other neurological diseases, a fractured leg, sprained ankle, limited balance, and an exoskeleton. Although crutches and canes are imperative to walking assistance and rehabilitation for many individuals, the designs have not significantly changed in the past century. Users frequently report problems with comfort and the inability to walk long distances. The discomfort and lack of long-term walking partially stems from the rubber point tip that is unstable and does not provide any assistance propelling the person forward. A point or constant radius tip cannot assist or resist the user during swinging or rolling over the crutch tip, and all forward progression forces are generated by the users pushing themselves forward over the crutch. The aim of this project is to develop advanced and low-cost walking crutches/canes that are able to passively and effectively assist users during level ground or up-hill walking, while also enhancing control and balance during standing or down-hill walking.

Placing a properly designed kinetic shape on the crutch/cane tip can generate a rolling force based on the vertical force applied by the user?s weight. These crutch/cane roll-over shapes can either be passive and predetermined or actively changing shapes, which can accommodate different walking environments and user preferences. An actively changing crutch/cane tip also allows for the crutch/cane to stand up on its own as needed so users are able to free their hands for other everyday motions, for example shaking someone's hand or pushing an elevator button. Having a crutch/cane be able to stand up independently is a feature that several chronic users of canes are excited about.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There are approximately six million people in the US that use crutches for everyday mobility, and the number of individuals using assistive devices for mobility is growing faster than the general population. To better understand the needs of these individuals, we interviewed over one hundred people as part of this project. A common point made by many of those we interviewed is that crutch users need more effective crutches to enable their daily mobility. By “effective”, the short- and long-term crutch users detailed one of several desired improvements. The most highly valued need is that of reducing fatigue. In fact, long-term crutch users are highly sensitive to crutch usage effort increases and are able to sense a change of just ounces in their crutches or crutch tips.  So, keeping the weight to a minimum is important, but adding assistance in propelling the user forward was also found to be a desirable trait. The second and third most desired crutch properties are downhill slope walking control and uphill walking assistance. We also found that crutch tips are replaced multiple times per year, but the crutches are only replaced every few years; thus, being able to achieve the benefits by only changing the crutch tip was seen as a valuable proposition. Other stated desires include crutch tip looks, traction, and durability.  We found a recurring trend that comfort, fatigue, and stability when going down hills were significant hindrances to crutch use. Our kinetic crutch tip directly addresses two of these issues, fatigue and stability, which indirectly also helps the comfort of using crutches. Of those interviewed, 71% stated that fatigue and/or stability was a major issue for them when using crutches.  The conclusion of this program is that there is a need for this technology, so future efforts will continue to advance this technology.
